text: NF-kappa B is a pleiotropic regulator of a variety of genes implicated in the cellular response to injury .

This function has been attributed to the coordinated binding of subunits of NF-kappa B to distinct regions of the promoter elements of numerous genes , including cytokines , growth factor receptors , and adhesion molecules .

Antisense phosphorothioate oligonucleotides to the <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunits of the NF-kappa B complex were used to define the physiologic role of this transcription factor in resting and stimulated granulocytes .
A reduction in the expression of <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was produced by treatment with the phosphorothioate antisense oligodeoxynucleotide .

text: This reduction was accompanied by rapid changes in the cellular adhesion of dimethyl sulfoxide-differentiated HL-60 leukemia cells stimulated by 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol 13-acetate ( TPA ) .
These effects were characterized by a marked reduction in <extra_id_0> CD11b <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> integrin expression on the surface of treated cells .

text: Furthermore , the <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antisense oligomer effectively abolished an upregulation of <extra_id_0> CD11b <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> that was produced by formyl-met-leu-phe and TPA .

text: However , the <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antisense phosphorothioate oligodeoxynucleotide had no significant effect on the production of reactive oxygen intermediates or on phagocytosis by these cells .
These findings indicate that antisense oligomers to <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can be used to define the role of NF-kappa B in the activation pathways of neutrophils .
